rules:
1.2 - Does the price of a private company drop by 5 for no sale in the
first round?

rules.1812:
No. If none of the initial set of Private Companies are put up for auction, a
new random set of Private Companies are chosen and the game starts again.
rules.1817:
No. If no private companies are purchased they are all
removed from the game.
rules.1825:
No. One private per player dealt at random and sold compulsorily. With more
than 4 players, the others get LNWR shares.
rules.1826: No. First player must buy the first private if round passes out.
rules.1846:
No. Players draw from a mixed deck of private companies and dummy
cards, choosing which items to keep. The last drawn private company may be passed round
the table, reducing in price by $10  each time it is passed on, until it is either
bought, or taken at no cost.
rules.1851: No. One private per player is dealt at random and sold compulsorily.
rules.1859:
No. If all players pass, the player putting the private up for
auction receives it for free.
rules.1860: No. All auctions start at zero.
rules.1861:
Yes, for all private companies. Any private company price may
drop to zero as a result of this.
rules.1867:
Yes, for all private companies. Any private company price may
drop to zero as a result of this.
rules.1873:
Not applicable. But after the initial auction, a Dutch auction
commences with 10 subtracted whenever all players pass.
rules.1889: Yes, Takamatsu ER(A) only. Must buy if 0 Yen.
rules.1893:
No, but any starting package certificates unsold after the first
round are offered for sale in the next SR. If nobody wants the offered certificate, its
price is reduced by 10 until the offered price is 50% (rounded up) of the initial price.
If nobody wants it at that price, the player offering it has to buy it, or if they do not
have enough cash, the player to their right. This procedure is repeated for the remaining
starting package certificates.
rules.18USA:
No. If no private companies are purchased they are all
removed from the game.
rules.18NW: No. First player must buy the first private if round passes out.
rules.1829 Mainline:
Not applicable - initial share holdings are dealt, not
sold.
rules.1830NL: Yes, but the second company, not the first, which pays no dividend.
rules.1869 USA West:
No. The price for all unsold privates drops by 10 if a
stock round ends with one or more privates unsold. In the second stock round, if nobody
buys the first private, the first player must buy it for 1.
rules.18??:
No. Any set of private companies not bid on when all players pass is
removed from the game.
rules.18C2C:
Yes, but after an operating round. May apply to the Great River
Shipping Company and/or the Schuykill Valley Railroad.
rules.18FL:
No. Privates are bought at face value, following a bidding
process to determine the order in which players make their purchases. 18US has Concessions
instead of Privates.
rules.18US:
No. Privates are bought at face value, following a bidding
process to determine the order in which players make their purchases. 18US has Concessions
instead of Privates.
rules.18GB:
No. If any privates are not sold when all players pass, those with
bids a re sold and the unsold privates are redcued in price by 10.
rules.18GL:
No. If all players pass without buying the first private, the player
with the priority must buy it for its face value.
rules.18MW: No. There are in effect seven simultaneous auctions for the privates.
rules.18Neb:
No. If all palyers pass consecutively during the first stock round,
the face value for any items without bids is reduced by 10. This may happen more than
once.
rules.18NL: Yes, for the first two privates only.
rules.18OE:
Yes. If all players pass before the entire opening packet has been
sold, all items on the topmost row are reduced by 5.
rules.18SA:
No. If all players pass before all private companies are sold, the
unsold private companies are removed from the game.
rules.18VA:
No. A series of auction is undertaken. Any private that has not been bid on at
the end of each auction is reduced in price by 10.
rules.Steam Over Holland:
No. A number of privates equal to the number of
players are selected at random and auctioned in sequence. If nobody bids the private is
removed from the game.
